Article.ArticleTitle: Long-Term Exposure to Low-Level <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and Mortality among the Elderly Population in the Southeastern United States.

AbstractText: Mounting evidence has shown that long-term exposure to fine particulate matter [PM <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mspace></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mi>m</mi></mrow></math> in aerodynamic diameter (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>)] and ozone (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) can increase mortality. However, the health effects associated with long-term exposure to nitrogen dioxide (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) are less clear, in particular the evidence is scarce for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> at low levels that are below the current international guidelines.

We constructed a population-based full cohort comprising all Medicare beneficiaries (aged <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo>≥</mo><mn>65</mn></mrow></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13,590,387</mn></mrow></math>) in the southeastern United States from 2000 to 2016, and we then further defined the below-guideline cohort that included only those who were always exposed to low-level <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, that is, with annual means below the current World Health Organization guidelines (i.e., <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo>≤</mo><mn>21</mn><mtext> ppb</mtext></mrow></math>). We applied previously estimated spatially and temporally resolved <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentrations and assigned annual means to study participants based on their ZIP code of residence. Cox proportional hazards models were used to examine the association between long-term exposure to low-level <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and all-cause mortality, adjusting for potential confounders.

About 71.1% of the Medicare beneficiaries in the southeastern United States were always exposed to low-level <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> over the study period. We observed an association between long-term exposure to low-level <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and all-cause mortality, with a <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>hazard ratio </mtext><mo>(</mo><mtext>HR</mtext><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo></mrow></math> 1.042 (95% CI: 1.040, 1.045) in single-pollutant models and a <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>HR</mtext><mo>=</mo></mrow></math> 1.047 (95% CI: 1.045, 1.049) in multipollutant models (adjusting for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>), per <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext>-ppb</mtext></mrow></math> increase in annual <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentrations. The penalized spline indicates a linear exposure-response relationship across the entire <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> exposure range. Medicare enrollees who were White, female, and residing in urban areas were more vulnerable to long-term <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> exposure.

Using a large and representative cohort, we provide epidemiological evidence that long-term exposure to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, even below the national and global ambient air quality guidelines, was approximately linearly associated with a higher risk of mortality among older adults, independent of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> exposure. Improving air quality by reducing <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>NO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> emissions, therefore, may yield significant health benefits. https://doi.org/10.1289/EHP9044.
